awd_titl_txt: Near-Infrared Fluorescent Graphene Nanomaterials for Detection of Trace Analytes
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program and co-funding from the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms-B Program in the Division of Chemistry, Dr. Julia Zhao and her group at the University of North Dakota are devising a new approach to chemical imaging based on graphene-based nanomaterials.  When illuminated with light of the proper wavelength, these materials fluoresce in the near infrared (NIR) region of the electromagnetic spectrum.  This offers lower background signals (and therefore higher sensitivity) and deeper penetration than conventional imaging agents. This in turns enables imaging the inner structures of biological and other, with important potential applications in areas such as environmental science, biology, and national security. Dr. Zhao is reaching out to engage Tribal Colleges and Universities in North Dakota both in this work and more generally.  A key aim is to encourage students from this underrepresented group to consider science as a career option. 

The technical objectives of this project are three-fold: 1) Synthesis. The development of a series of graphene-based near-infrared fluorescent (NIRF) nanomaterials for sensitive detection and imaging of trace analytes (especially in biosamples). The distinct features of these NIRF nanomaterials are: a) intense fluorescence signals, b) tunable fluorescence wavelengths, c) high water solubility, and d) large surface area. To achieve this goal, the PI is developing new methods for making graphene-based NIRF nanomaterials with various dimensions and reduction levels to fine-tune the fluorescence wavelengths and intensities. 2) Fundamental study. Study of the geometric, compositional, and dimensional effects of graphene materials on their fluorescence properties, including fluorescence quantum yield, lifetime and wavelengths. 3) Application. The implementation of the NIRF nanomaterials in bioanalysis and bioimaging. The NIR region favors low background signals and deeper penetration of radiation. Highly sensitive detection and in vitro/vivo imaging can be accomplished using NIRF nanomaterials. Targeted properties include high quantum yield, tunability of excitation and emission wavelengths, minimal photo-bleaching, and minimal overlap between excitation and emission bands.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Dr. Julia Zhao and her group at the University of North Dakota have developed eight graphene-based fluorescent nanomaterials. When illuminated with light of the proper wavelength, these nanomaterials fluoresce in the near infrared (NIR) region of the electromagnetic spectrum. This offers lower background signals (and therefore higher sensitivity) and deeper penetration than conventional imaging agents. This in turn enables imaging the inner structures of biological samples.

To understand whether/how optical properties of these nanomaterials change when composition of the nanomaterials is different, in collaboration with theoretical chemists, a comprehensive study of light absorption properties of the nanomaterials was conducted.  The finding in mechanism would prove a useful approach to design novel nanomaterials with a higher intensity of light for sensitive imaging of target cells. Six types of applications were successfully implemented which clearly demonstrated the advantages of the developed graphene-based nanomaterials in bioapplications.

Dr. Zhao reached out to engage tribal high/middle school students in science activities.  With support from the North Dakota EPSCoR Nature program, Dr. Zhao has led her research group to design and deliver three STEM projects to North Dakota American Indian Tribal High School and Middle School students during the grant period. A key aim is to encourage students from this underrepresented group to consider science as a career option. To host the activity, Dr. Zhao and her graduate students traveled monthly to the five reservations during weekends in fall semesters although North Dakota winter is harsh with extreme weather conditions. During the pandemic, to motivate study-at-home students to continue active STEM education, Dr. Zhao and her students developed a project of "Observation of Protein Breakdown Process in Various Environmental Conditions". By doing this project, students had a deeper understanding of environmental conditions in maintaining normal protein structures to preserve healthy life.

During the pandemic, Dr. Zhao has led her students to initiate and conduct several outreach activities to promote science among communities. To help the public better understand the science behind mask use, Dr. Zhao with her four Ph.D. students, in collaboration with a polymer scientist colleague, delivered a Science Café webinar in North Dakota. Materials design was introduced. Materials properties, chemistry, and mechanism of filtration were discussed. Additionally, four of Dr. Zhao’s Ph.D. students have made a video of a “Nanoscience Lab Tour” and a video of “Introduction to Analytical Instrumentation” to serve the local community.

The NSF support has resulted in 31 peer-reviewed journal articles, two granted US patents, four Ph.D. dissertations and one Master thesis. A total of 25 participants have directly worked on the project including ten graduate students, five undergraduate students, three postdocs, four high school students, and three faculty members. The research goals proposed have been successfully accomplished.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/08/2023
Modified by: Julia Xiaojun Zhao
